instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00597: What is 820-00597? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PMP_SLP_S3_L: What is PMP_SLP_S3_L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S3_L When you see PMP_SLP_S3_L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S3_L.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: So, I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> logic board to replace the one in a 2017 21.5 4K iMac.  It worked fine when I got it, powered up fine, was able to install MacOS on it.  All done on the bench of course.  I decided before putting it in the chassis to reapply the thermal paste for the CPU and GPU and look over the board to make sure there weren't any issues.  I noticed a cap had been pulled up off the board (still attached on one side) and soldered it back in place. It was part of the Ethernet circuit, I can look up the specific one if it's important.  I also decided to swap the EFI rom chip from the original board so the serial number would match.  I had done it several times before on other boards with no issues. After these several steps, I put everything back together and the logic board won't power on.  It draws ~ 0.1Amps when power is applied, drops to 0.08 amps then stays there.  Strange thing is, if I short the power pads the logic board will act like it is powering off, dropping to 0.03 amps drawn.  If I then short the power pads it will go back up to 0.1 amps and do the same thing again.  I checked that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is being generated.  Also diagnostic LED 1 stays solid, it doesn't flicker.  None of the other LEDs come on.  Anyway, just wanted to see if anyone had any idea what might have happened to it.  I wanted to get this board working again because it's got the Radeon 560 4GB graphics.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"I also decided to swap the EFI rom chip from the original board so the serial number would match.  I had done it several times before on other boards with no issues."
Did you ever concern about ME region?
How do you think the PCH will feel with incorrect ME region?
STOP doing that.
Change the serial number manually with HxD and fix the Fsys checksum; videos available on Internet (even on this forum).
Or clean ME region in the old BIOS chip.

Where did you find <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in this MLB?

Did you try disconnecting CMOS cell?
Can you tell us in schematic, which was the unsoldered cap?
Do you get <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Thanks for the quick response.  Unfortunately, I've gone out of town, but I'll be back in a couple days.  I'll post the info as soon as I get back.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
Ok, I will take your advice regarding the BIOS chip.

There is no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on this iMac board.  I think the equivelant <SIGNAL>P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.  On <CAPACITOR>C6922</CAPACITOR> I get 3.7V.  On <CHIP>U6970</CHIP> I get 3.8V on PIN 8, <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.  Pin 7 which is 
<SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S5</SIGNAL>, I read 23.17V, which is obviously not good.  All other values on <CHIP>U6970</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6920</CHIP> are nominal.

I've tried without the CMOS cell.  The cap that got detached was <CAPACITOR>C4003</CAPACITOR>. 

Again, thanks.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Ignore the 23.17V reading, that was a mistake on my part I think.  I found <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S0</SIGNAL>, on <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U8450</CHIP>, and they are both missing (0V) but <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> is present.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"Pin 7 which is <SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S5</SIGNAL>, I read 23.17V, which is obviously not good."
Why do you think that?
Don't make wrong assumption so easy, try to understand a schematic first.

You can't make any relation between actual <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> from a Macbook.
BTW, you can check <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at L6930/<CAPACITOR>C6932</CAPACITOR> (not <CAPACITOR>C6922</CAPACITOR>).

"Also diagnostic LED 1 stays solid, it doesn't flicker"
So <SIGNAL>12V_S5</SIGNAL> must be there.
That's the reason nobody asked about U/<TRANSISTOR>Q6970</TRANSISTOR>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> also needs more than 20V on its Gate to work properly.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse (3V->0V->3V) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
If detected, you should catch a pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> too; check at same time with trigger event.
Use J5120 pads instead of power button.

<CAPACITOR>C4003</CAPACITOR> is not critical and you can leave it unsoldered without problems.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: I see the voltage drop on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, 3.3V -> 0V -> 3.3V (using J5120).  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> stays at 3.3V when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, unless I short it (at J5120) until the board turns off, then it drops to 0V.  <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> stays at 0V during all of this.  I measured these voltages at the respective test points.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
So you have stable 3V at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> when charger is connected?
That means PCH already started power on sequence; no need to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> level too.

Do you get voltage at L7650 and L7310?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
If I measure <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> to ground I get about 240 Ohm.  So if I measure the voltage to <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H</SIGNAL> on <CHIP>U8450</CHIP> I get ~12V, which stays steady if I short J5120.

Yes, I agree that I need assistance in understanding schematics.  If you have any suggestions on a guide that would help me, I would appreciate it.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PMP_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is at ~3.3V.  L7650 is ~5V to ground.  L7310 is at ~5V to L7650.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"L7310 is at ~5V to L7650"
No idea what you've meant.
I hope you don't have 5V at L7310.
Correct voltage is explained on page 63; Vout=1.8*(Rb/(Ra+Rb)), with Ra/b marked on the schematic (<RESISTOR>R7330</RESISTOR>/31).
In other words, 1.2V for DDR4 type.

"If I measure <SIGNAL>PM_EN_FET_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> to ground I get about 240 Ohm"
Nobody asked about ohm resistance there.
Be patient, you will understand schematics in time.
Just don't waste time with irrelevant checkings.

Post <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> voltages (pins 8, 9, 10, 14), when both <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> are present.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: If I measure L7310 to ground I have 0.048V.  Is that what I should be measuring it to?  The only reason I mentioned the ohm value was to see if you thought I had a short.  I'll measure the voltages from <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> in a bit and post those.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Voltages on <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> - Pin 8: 0V, Pin 9: 3.3V, Pin 10: 0.013V, Pin 14: 3.3V.  These are all measured to ground.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"all measured to ground"
Nobody expects to measure voltage in other way.

"Pin 10: 0.013V"
Don't you get L7310 voltage?
You've said <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is high.
Post <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> pins 1 to 6 voltages too.
Also check <CHIP>U7350</CHIP> and <CHIP>U8410</CHIP> output voltage.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: I wasn't sure that some voltages might not be able to be measured to common ground due to diodes restricting voltage direction. But I suppose the schematics would show where that was the case?  I'll post the other voltages as soon as I get a chance.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8500</CHIP> Voltages: Pin 1: 3.324V, Pin 2: 1.00V, Pin 3: 0.00V, Pin 4: 3.324V, Pin 5: 0.016V. Pin 6: 0.00V
<CHIP>U7350</CHIP> Voltage Out (Pin 1 & 2): 0V
<CHIP>U8410</CHIP> Voltage Out (Pin 8): 1.00V
I can't see why <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> Pin 10 and L7310 should have the same voltage, but the readings are the same: <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> Pin 10: 0.013V, L7310 Pin 1 & 2: 0.048V

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"I can't see why <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> Pin 10 and L7310 should have the same voltage"
Who said that?
Don't make assumptions based on wrong suppositions.
Output voltage is not same as its power good, but directly related.

"Pin 2: 1.00V"
Are you sure about this?
Is not good voltage; should be 3.3V, check it again.
If really bad, then check <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR>/11, which one is there.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Ok, I measured Pin 2 on <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> again.  It is 1.00V.  The schmetics say Pin 2 is <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL>, so wouldn't that be the proper voltage?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL>  is pulled high to 3.3V; did you check which resistor is mounted there?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Ok, hopefully we're looking at the same schematic.  Pin 2 on <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> is fed off <CHIP>U8410</CHIP> Pin 7.  There is a 10K resistor, <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR>, with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> on one side and <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL> on the other.  Both voltages are nominal: 3.3V for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_PWRCTL</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR> Pin 1 and 1.0V for <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR> Pin 2.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"1.0V for <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR> Pin 2"
That's no good; check if <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR> has 10K (measure it out of board).
If really good, try changing <CHIP>U8500</CHIP>.
If still the same, change <CHIP>U8410</CHIP>.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Alright, I checked <RESISTOR>R8410</RESISTOR> off the board and it came in at ~10K Ohm like it should.  So I replaced <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> as recommended and now I get 3.3V for <SIGNAL>PM_PGOOD_FET_P1V0_S3</SIGNAL>.  However, the board still won't power on.  Should I replace <CHIP>U8410</CHIP>?  I suppose I can go back and recheck all the other voltages.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
Don't tocuh <CHIP>U8410</CHIP>!
Don't you have correct <SIGNAL>1V0_S3</SIGNAL> on its pin 8?

Post again voltage on all <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> above mentioned pins.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: On <CHIP>U8410</CHIP> Pin 8 I have 1.0V.  The voltages for <CHIP>U8500</CHIP> are:  Pin 1: 3.325V, Pin 2: 3.322V, Pin 3: 3.325V, Pin 4: 3.325V, Pin 5: 3.325V. Pin 6: 3.325V, Pin 8: 3.271V, Pin 9: 3.325V, Pin 10: 3.319V, Pin 14: 3.326V

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8500</CHIP> looks good, so you must have voltage on various coils of the board.
Do you get 12V output now from <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
I get 0V output on Q450 (Pins 1, 2, 3).  I also have 0V on <SIGNAL>FET_EN_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> (Pin 4).  I do get 12V on <SIGNAL>PP12V_G3H_P12V_S0</SIGNAL> (Pin 5).

Just in case it helps, <CHIP>U8450</CHIP> voltages are as follows: Pin 1: 11.97V, Pin 2: 1.77V, Pin 5: 11.97V, Pin 6: 0V, PIN 7: 0V, Pin 8: 0.051V.  On <RESISTOR>R8542</RESISTOR>, Pin 1 has 3.3V (Pin 2 is connected to <CHIP>U8450</CHIP> Pin 8).

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U8450</CHIP>
Pin 2: 1.77V"
You've said to have 3.2V on pin 8/<CHIP>U8500</CHIP>; confirm that.
If yes, check the components in between.

<TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> is classic failure, you can try changing it directly.
May need to change <CHIP>U8450</CHIP> also.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Alright, looks like the issue was <CHIP>U8450</CHIP>.  I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> but it didn't fix the issue until I replaced <CHIP>U8450</CHIP>.  Hopefully this is all that's going to be needed.  Should I check or replace any other components?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Don't touch anything else, if machine works good.

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Can I ask what programmer would you recommend to flash the BIOS on this iMac?

threads.title: iMac 2017 21.5 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00597</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Logic Board Will Not Power On
threads.message: Any BIOS programmer should work; even the cheapest CH341A.
